G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(b).proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(b) and G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts giving rise to this claim occurred in Springfield, within Hampden County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 3(b) and G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts giving rise to this claim occurred in Springfield, within Hampden County.

Janos v. Morin, 967 N.E.2d 619 (Mass. Ap.raw_text: Janos v. Morin, 967 N.E.2d 619 (Mass. App. Ct. 2012)
Janos v. Morin, 967 N.E.2d 619 (Mass. Ap.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the placement and securing of objects on their property so as not to cause foreseeable harm to others. See Janos v. Morin, 967 N.E.2d 619 (Mass. App. Ct. 2012); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (1995).

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the placement and securing of objects on their property so as not to cause foreseeable harm to others. See Janos v. Morin, 967 N.E.2d 619 (Mass. App. Ct. 2012); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (1995).
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The court expressly reaffirms the general Massachusetts rule that a landowner owes a common-law duty of reasonable care in the use of its land, including toward travelers on adjacent highways, and must exercise reasonable care so as not to injure them. Although the holding here is that the landowner did not have the additional, broader duty to alter a state highway (e.g., build a bridge or install a light), the opinion clearly recognizes the baseline duty of reasonable care in the placement/use of conditions on one’s property so as not to create unreasonable risk of foreseeable harm to others.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware… Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful neighbor and foreseeable user of the shared driveway, a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent dangerous conditions arising from his property. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650 (2001).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The excerpted passage from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion by Justice Kaplan focusing on abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning the special treatment of trespassers. It does not specifically address duties between neighboring landowners or a duty to a lawful neighbor and foreseeable user of a shared driveway. While the broader Mounsey decision concerns general premises liability and reasonable care, this cited portion does not clearly establish the particular neighbor/driveway duty claimed in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650.raw_text: Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650 (2001)
Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful neighbor and foreseeable user of the shared driveway, a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent dangerous conditions arising from his property. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650 (2001).
Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the existence, scope, and enforceability of an attorney’s lien under G.L. c. 221, § 50, arising from litigation over insurance proceeds and a constructive trust. It does not address premises liability, duties owed between neighbors, or any obligation to exercise reasonable care to prevent dangerous conditions on property or a shared driveway. Citing Sullivan v. Creed for that proposition is therefore inaccurate; the case provides no authority on the duty described in the proposition.
Sullivan v. Creed, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 650.relevant_excerpt:
General Laws c. 221, § 50, as appearing in St. 1945, c. 397, § 1, establishes an attorney’s lien, providing, in relevant part:
“From the authorized commencement of an action, counterclaim or other proceeding in any court... the attorney who appears for a client . . . shall have a lien for his reasonable fees and expenses upon his client’s cause of action, counterclaim or claim, upon the judgment, decrees or other order in his client’s favor entered or made in such proceeding, and upon the proceeds derived therefrom” (emphasis supplied).

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant breached this duty by leaving a tall aluminum ladder unsecured and leaning against a fence bordering the shared driveway despite prior warnings and foreseeable risks. See Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000) (landowner negligent when failing to correct a known danger).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The proposition describes a landowner’s negligence for leaving an unsecured ladder despite known danger. Glidden v. Maglio involves a scaffolding collapse on a construction job and turns on plaintiffs’ failure to prove causation and, secondarily, lack of evidence that the landowner knew or should have known of any hazardous condition. The court affirms summary judgment for the landowner and explicitly notes the absence of proof of any known dangerous condition, so the case does not stand for the cited negligence principle and in fact cuts against it.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care)."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that high winds could easily dislodge an unsecured ladder, posing a foreseeable risk of property damage or injury. See Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) (foreseeability is key in negligence).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case discusses foreseeability as a component of duty in negligence, but it does not involve or address high winds, unsecured ladders, or risks specific to those conditions. Its holding concerns a landowner’s duty to remedy an open and obvious dangerous condition (a trampoline next to a shallow pool) when the landowner can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will nonetheless encounter the risk. Using this case for the specific proposition about high winds dislodging an unsecured ladder misstates the factual and legal context, even though the case does confirm foreseeability’s importance generally.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm… notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’”

Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.raw_text: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107 (2000)
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable precautions was the direct and proximate cause of the damage to Plaintiff’s vehicle. See Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107 (2000) (requiring proof of causation between breach and harm).
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.case_name: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.support_reasoning: The case is an employment discrimination and retaliation decision under Massachusetts anti-discrimination law, not a negligence or property-damage case. While it discusses causation in the sense of whether discriminatory or retaliatory animus was a determinative factor in an employee’s termination, it does not address negligence, ‘reasonable precautions,’ motor vehicles, or proximate cause of damage to property. Thus, using this case as authority for a proposition about a defendant’s failure to take reasonable precautions being the direct and proximate cause of damage to a vehicle is inaccurate and out of context.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.relevant_excerpt: “To succeed on a claim of retaliation, ‘the plaintiff must prove that [he] reasonably and in good faith believed that the [employer] was engaged in wrongful discrimination, that [he] acted reasonably in response to [his] belief, and that the [employer’s] desire to retaliate against [him] was a determinative factor in its decision to terminate [his] employment.’ Tate v. Department of Mental Health, 419 Mass. 356, 364 (1995).”

Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.raw_text: Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323 (1982)
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages are all reasonably certain and foreseeable within the meaning of Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323 (1982) and Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm’n, 450 Mass. 178 (2007).
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.support_reasoning: Cimino addresses foreseeability in the sense of proximate cause—i.e., whether injuries to highway travelers and emotional distress to a nearby father are within the foreseeable risk of overserving an intoxicated patron. It does not address whether “all” of a plaintiff’s claimed damages must be reasonably certain or the degree of certainty required for proof and calculation of damages. The opinion focuses on duty, foreseeability, and proximate cause, not on the standard of reasonable certainty of damages, so it does not provide authority for the proposition as phrased.
Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 3.relevant_excerpt: “It is only necessary for the plaintiff to prove that the defendant took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. … A jury may also infer that service of liquor to an intoxicated patron is the proximate cause of injuries sustained by a traveler who suffers direct injury by reason of a vehicle being operated by the patron in a manner that is affected by his intoxication.”

Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm\u20.raw_text: Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm’n, 450 Mass. 178 (2007)
Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm\u20.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages are all reasonably certain and foreseeable within the meaning of Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323 (1982) and Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm’n, 450 Mass. 178 (2007).
Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm\u20.support_reasoning: Griefen is a criminal case about the voluntariness of a defendant’s inculpatory statement and the standards for reviewing a motion to suppress. The opinion does not address civil damages, nor the concepts of reasonable certainty or foreseeability of damages under Cimino v. Milford Keg or any other civil damages framework. Citing Griefen for the proposition that a plaintiff’s damages are reasonably certain and foreseeable misstates the subject and holding of the case.
Griefen v. Boston Water & Sewer Comm\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘A statement is voluntary if it is the product of a ‘rational intellect’ and a ‘free will.’ … To determine whether a defendant made her statement voluntarily, a judge examines whether, ‘in light of the totality of the circumstances … the will of the defendant was overborne to the extent that the statement was not the result of a free and voluntary act.’ … Under the ‘totality of the circumstances’ test, we consider all of the relevant circumstances surrounding the statement and the individual characteristics and conduct of the defendant.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: C. Prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d).proposition: D. Costs of this action pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d);

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Plaintiff demands trial by jury on all issues so triable pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.
